history.content:
You need 5 units of technical electives / 4 units of outside engineering to graduate from EECS. Not seeing that here?

isnt the 5 outside engineering no longer required? As for the 4 technical, data 8 works
You need 5 units of technical electives / 4 units of outside engineering to graduate from EECS. Not seeing that here?

children.subject:
OP: those classes are already taken because that is what I am interested in. I don't appreciate your lack of respect. C100 is an extremely valuable course in the rise of data science, and I'm assuming you haven't taken 169, so how would you know?

as far as physics, I hate physics and didn't like EE 16a And just want to get them done to graduate.  

My question was more towards is this allowed/ do I have all the requirements

Everyone who I've talked to who said they took 169 also said there was nothing you wouldn't learn at your first big internship. I personally think that while you're in school, you should strive to first learn all the theory, then learn stuff that can be used in industry because that stuff can always be picked up on the job. 

Also 16B is critical for data science. It's basically 127-lite. It would still be in your best interest to do 16B ASAP

If you hate physics, then 7A/B are not as important, but then at that point, maybe just a pure DS or CS major would be better suited for you? It seems like the classes that make EECS different from L&S (16B, 7A, 7B) are also all classes that you hate. If you're going to do Haas you need all 7 breadths anyways, so you're not saving any breadths, and you're going to have a lot more trouble matching upper divs for 3 majors compared to two.

Sorry if I sounded disrespectful. I've talked to too many freshmen wanting to rush through classes for the sake of getting three majors done and not really think about why three majors are needed in the first place.
As funny as the name sounds, 16B actually teaches you much of the critical math needed for statistical analysis and ML, which data science certainly uses.

Gonna add to this: Depends on what you're shooting for re: research or industry, and if industry, what sort of role.

If you're going for more analytics/business intelligence, this looks pretty good. Less technical, maybe you'll write some SQL or Python once in a while, but it'll mostly be Excel. This honestly takes you pretty far even at firms like McKinsey, but it's ultimately more oriented towards nontechnical people.

If you're going for more hardcore data science, then this is totally, totally, totally insufficient. I'm sorry, but 188 really is a joke upper div and won't help you here. C100 isn't quite a joke but it's not far from it either - it will make you a good python monkey and help with analytics, but that's it, and most people pick up C100 in their internships anyways. If you want to build your own models or get into quantitative roles like on Wall Street, you'll definitely not have the rigor to make it unless you have at least 126/127/189 level skills in statistics and math (Stat 134/140 aren't bad, but pale in comparison to 126) - and even then, you'll need more rigor elsewhere. 169 is pretty good; if you do a data science oriented internship, then you might want to get SWE skills in this class and that's fine.

Overall though, you really are robbing yourself of a rigorous education and a lot of brain training that'll help you down the road. I'm not just a EECS looking down on Haas students person either; I actually was accepted and turned it down after hearing from so many Haas students that they felt like they wasted their time.

Why would you do this though? You're robbing yourself of a CS education by only taking joke upper divs like 188, 169 and c100 in order to make time for DS/UGBA classes. 170 is the only rigorous class you have there. 

There's 0 point to 3 majors. In fact, I would even say that 90% of the time, your second major is useless. 

It' also foolish to push 7A/B and 16B that late. Those are lower div classes. The idea is to have them done before starting upper divs. Push c100, ugba 133, and 188 and do 7A, 16B, and 7B instead. 16B and 7B are useful for EECS.

Following up from my student response; yes I think this works.

However, like my peers, I will strongly caution against this.

What are you going to get out of this? 

Perhaps you have a passion for business or something, but that's not really best served by a Haas degree that has very little actual skills, and has comparable job placement to engineering degrees anyway. You're not really better served by the degree, assuming you're not MET, because you're not garnering better roles or connections from the program so much as you're getting in the way of improving engineering skills or soft skills developed through engineering-oriented opportunities like a fellowship at a VC, the SCET program, etc.

Likewise, with the data science degree, I go as far to say as you should certainly collect it if you're going into Haas because you'll get the 7 breadths done.

However, consider this. The world of EECS is very broad, and is singularly defined by hardworking imaginative people. Bluntly, if your goal is to work at a hedge fund and make bank, that's incredibly suboptimal decision planning [given that very few people survive the industry in a remotely profitable way, you'd make more money in literally any other career when you look at the hours put in, including service and consulting work, and that fundamentally, the kind of entities that invest in hedge funds and private equity are rarely friendly institutions and more commonly extreme criminals and destructive individuals that can't get their money clean elsewhere]. Consider what EECS can offer you at a higher level. Skip out on BS 'learn to handshake' Haas courses, and instead work with honorable folks, like Miki Lustig, who tirelessly develops revolutionary medical technologies from novel MRI detection systems to bio-printed medical devices, or Ken Goldberg, whose AutoLab designs autonomous robotics for all kinds of necessary tasks, like Phillipine disaster relief, making beds for the disabled and developing surgery robotics, among soooooooo many others. In fact, look through the work at these labs: https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Research/Areas/Centers/. Ask yourself about the kind of person you really want to be, separate of anything except what your core capabilities are, and I think you'll identify a lot with these people. Moreover, Berkeley teaches that all existing systems are human and fallible. If you push yourself in EECS, take high level and grad courses, rigorously engage with the amazing, energetic community, you'll get so much money it'll make your eyes bleed. Someone working on self-driving cars, or ML at Google out of college, is making at least 250k a year fresh out, and that's just the starting point. Tons of professors here have commercialized ground breaking work and made millions, if not billions, and they return to the university because they want to do more and give back to the world. 

In summary, I wish I had known this when I was younger, and was less arrogant and hard-headed. In fact, I still have the google doc on how I was going to finish in 2 years and get a PhD and make bank at a Renaissance Technologies or similar hedge fund. Please believe me when I tell you the guidelines made by Professor Anant Sahai and Co. are sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo well thought out, that they are there for your true help guidance and development. Literally read Sahai's posts here and on his faculty site, or meet with him and several other faculty in person, and I think you'll see that if you open yourself up to this material deeply, not just hitting out pre-reqs to collect a degree, but really and creatively think about this stuff, you will be rewarded in a way few people alive have ever experienced.

history.content:
For a CoE major (EECS) "You must complete a minimum of 5 upper division technical courses distinct to each major (e.g. 5 classes beyond any that overlap)." 

https://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/majors-minors/simultaneous-degrees

children.subject: @nicole How does that relate to l and s majors, where the rule is completely different?

history.content:
Hi,

I am currently in my sophomore year and was confused on the rules between overlapping majors between l and s and other majors. Specifically I was considering doing EECS and Haas. If I were given the opportunity to join Haas, I realized I was basically completing the Data Science major.  

I read that 2 upper divs can match per major. Would that mean I could use Data 100 and CS 188 as overlapped with EECS & UGBA 104 & 134 as overlapped with Haas. If that is the case, would the degree plan above provide me all three degrees?
history.subject: Triple Major/Haas,EECS, Data-Science
